facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 61 of 1954 was filed as an appeal under Article 132(1) of the Constitution from the High Court of Nagpur's judgment dated 4th November 1953 in Civil Miscellaneous Petition No. 174 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 61 of 1954. Appeal under Article 132 1  of the Constitution of India from the Judgment and Order dated the 4th November 1953 of the High Court of Judicature at Nagpur in Civil Miscella

facts.text: Appellant and respondents 1 to 5 were nominated for election to the House of the People from Hoshangabad Constituency in Madhya Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant and respondents 1 to 5 herein were duly nominated for election to the House of the People from the Hoshangabad Constituency in the State of Madhya Pradesh. Respondents 4 and 5 subsequently withdrew from the election, leaving the contest to the other candidates.

facts.text: Respondents 4 and 5 withdrew from the election.

anchor.surface_text: Respondents 4 and 5 subsequently withdrew from the election, leaving the contest to the other candidates. At the polling the appellant secured 65,201 votes the first respondent 65,375 votes and the other candidates far less and the Returning Officer accordingly declared the first respondent duly elected.

facts.text: At polling, appellant secured 65,201 votes, first respondent 65,375 votes, and Returning Officer declared first respondent elected.

anchor.surface_text: At the polling the appellant secured 65,201 votes the first respondent 65,375 votes and the other candidates far less and the Returning Officer accordingly declared the first respondent duly elected. The appellant then filed Election Petition No. 180 of 1952 for setting aside the election on the ground inter alia that 301 out of the votes counted in favour of the first respondent were liable to be rejected under Rule 47 1 c of Act No. XLIII of 1951 on the ground that the ballot papers did not have the distinguishing marks prescribed under Rule 28, and that by reason of their improper reception, the result of the election had been materially affected.

facts.text: Appellant filed Election Petition No. 180 of 1952 to set aside the election alleging 301 votes for first respondent invalid under Rule 47(1)(c) due to lack of prescribed distinguishing marks.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then filed Election Petition No. 180 of 1952 for setting aside the election on the ground inter alia that 301 out of the votes counted in favour of the first respondent were liable to be rejected under Rule 47 1 c of Act No. XLIII of 1951 on the ground that the ballot papers did not have the distinguishing marks prescribed under Rule 28, and that by reason of their improper reception, the result of the election had been materially affected. Rule 28 is as follows The ballot papers to be used for the purpose of voting at an election to which this Chapter applies shall contain a serial number and such distinguishing marks as the Election Commission may decide.

facts.text: Election Commission decided green bar for Parliamentary constituencies ballot papers and brown bar for State Assembly.

anchor.surface_text: Under this rule, the Election Commission had decided that the ballot papers for the Parliamentary Constituencies should bear a green bar printed near the left margin, and that those for the State Assembly should bear a brown bar. What happened in this case was that voters for the House of the People in polling stations Nos. 316 and 317 in Sobhapur were given ballot papers with brown bar intended for the State Assembly, instead of ballot papers with green bar which had to be used for the House of the People.

facts.text: At polling stations Nos. 316 and 317 in Sobhapur, voters for House of the People received brown bar ballot papers instead of green bar.

anchor.surface_text: What happened in this case was that voters for the House of the People in polling stations Nos. 316 and 317 in Sobhapur were given ballot papers with brown bar intended for the State Assembly, instead of ballot papers with green bar which had to be used for the House of the People. The total number of votes so polled was 443, out of which 62 were in favour of the appellant, 301 in favour of the first respondent, and the remaining in favour of the other candidates.

facts.text: Total votes at Sobhapur stations 316 and 317: 443, with 62 for appellant, 301 for first respondent.

anchor.surface_text: The total number of votes so polled was 443, out of which 62 were in favour of the appellant, 301 in favour of the first respondent, and the remaining in favour of the other candidates. Now, Rule 47 1 c enacts that a ballot paper contained in a ballot box shall be rejected if it bears any serial number or mark different from the- serial numbers or marks of ballot papers authorised for use at the polling station or the polling booth at which the ballot box in which it was found was used.

facts.text: First respondent contested the petition claiming Rule 47 directory and defect cured by Election Commission.

anchor.surface_text: The first respondent contested the petition. He pleaded that the Returning Officer at Sobbapur had rightly accepted the 301 votes, because Rule 47 was directory and not mandatory , and that further the votes had been accepted as valid by the Election Commission, and the defect, if any, had been cured.

facts.text: First respondent filed recrimination petition under section 97 alleging wrong ballot papers at polling station No. 299 Malkajra and No. 371 Bammangaon rejected by RO, giving him 117 more votes.

anchor.surface_text: He also filed a recrimination petition under section 97 of Act No. XLIII of 1951, and therein pleaded inter alia that at polling station No. 299 at Malkajra and at polling station No. 371 at Bammangaon ballot papers intended for use in the State Legislature election had been wrongly issued to voters to the House of the People by mistake of the polling officers, that all those votes had been wrongly rejected by the Returning Officer, and that if they had been counted, he would have got 117 votes more than the appellant.

facts.text: Election Tribunal by majority held Rule 47(1)(c) mandatory but result not materially affected, dismissed petition unanimously on that ground.

anchor.surface_text: The Election Tribunal held by a majority that Rule 47 1 c was mandatory, and that the 301 ballot papers found in the box of the first respondent bearing the wrong mark should not have been counted while the third Member was of the opinion that rule was merely directory, and that the Returning Officer had the power to accept them. The Tribunal, however, was unanimous in holding that the result of the election had not been materially affected by the erroneous reception of the votes, and on that ground dismissed the petition.

facts.text: Appellant moved High Court of Nagpur under Articles 226 and 227 for certiorari to quash Tribunal decision.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then moved the High Court of Nagpur under articles 226 and 227 of the Constitution for the issue of a writ of certiorari or other order or direction for quashing the decision of the Election Tribunal on the ground that it was illegal and without jurisdiction.

facts.text: High Court dismissed the petition by majority opinion.

anchor.surface_text: The petition was dismissed in accordance with the majority opinion. The learned Judges, however, granted a certificate under article 132 1 , and that is how this appeal comes before this Court.

facts.text: High Court granted certificate under Article 132(1) allowing appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges, however, granted a certificate under article 132 1 , and that is how this appeal comes before this Court. The first question that arises for decision in this appeal is whether High Courts have jurisdiction under article 226 to issue writs against decisions of Election Tribunals.

facts.text: Returning Officer at Hoshangabad obtained approval from Election Commission before counting the wrong ballot papers.

anchor.surface_text: The Returning Officer at Hoshangabad reported to the Chief Electoral Officer, Madhya Pradesh that wrong ballot papers had been issued owing to the mistake of the polling officers, and obtained the approval of the Commission for their being included, before the votes were counted.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on December 9, 1954 by Venkatarama Ayyar J.

anchor.surface_text: 1954. December 9. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by VENKATARAMA AYYAR J.-The appellant and respondents 1 to 5 herein were duly nominated for election to the House of the People from the Hoshangabad Constituency in the State of Madhya Pradesh.

facts.text: Election Tribunal records sent to District Judge or Chief Judge of Small Causes under section 103 after pronouncement.

anchor.surface_text: Under section 103 of Act No. XLIII of 1951 the Tribunal is directed to send the records of the case after the order is pronounced either to the relative District Judge or to the Chief Judge of the Court of Small Causes, and there is no legal impediment to a writ being issued to those officers to transmit the record to the High Court.

facts.text: Supreme Court held Rule 47(1)(c) is mandatory.

anchor.surface_text: (approx position based on context)

facts.text: Supreme Court quashed Tribunal and High Court decisions, set aside the election.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal must accordingly be allowed, the decisions of the High Court and the Tribunal quashed and the whole election set aside.

facts.text: Margin between appellant and first respondent was 174 votes.

anchor.surface_text: if that had been done, the first respondent would have lost the lead of 174 votes, and that he himself would have secured the largest number of votes.

issues.text: The first question that arises for decision in this appeal is whether High Courts have jurisdiction under article 226 to issue writs against decisions of Election Tribunals.

anchor.surface_text: The first question that arises for decision in this appeal is whether High Courts have jurisdiction under article 226 to issue writs against decisions of Election Tribunals. That article confers on High Courts power to issue appropriate writs to any person or authority within their territorial jurisdiction, in terms absolute and unqualified, and Election Tribunals functioning within the territorial jurisdiction of the High Courts would fall within the sweep of that power.

issues.text: whether having regard to its nature such a writ for quashing can be issued to review the decision of a Tribunal, which has ceased to exist.

anchor.surface_text: tion in the High Court under article 226 to issue certiorari against a decision of an Election Tribunal, it is incapable of exercise for the reason that under the scheme of Act No. XLIII of 1951, the Tribunal is an ad hoc body set up for determination of a particular election petition, that it becomes functus officio when it pronounces its decision, and that thereafter there is no authority in existence to which the writ could be issued. The question thus raised is of considerable importance, on which there is little by way of direct authority and it has to be answered primarily on a consideration of the nature of a writ of certiorari to quash.

issues.text: whether the Election Tribunals are subject to the superintendence of the High Courts under article 227 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: We are also of opinion that the Election Tribunals are subject to the superintendence of the High Courts under article 227 of the Constitution, and that superintendence is both judicial and administrative.

issues.text: Then the question is whether there are proper grounds for the issue of certiorari in the present case.

anchor.surface_text: We must accordingly hold that the application of the appellant for a writ of certiorari and for other reliefs was maintainable under articles 226 and 227 of the Constitution. Then the question is whether there are proper grounds for the issue of certiorari in the present case. There was considerable argument before us as to the character and scope of the writ of certiorari and the conditions under which it could be issued.

issues.text: On the question whether Rule 47 1 c is mandatory

anchor.surface_text: Now the contention of Mr. N. C. Chatterjee for the appellant is that in reaching this conclusion the Tribunal had taken into consideration matters which are wholly extraneous to an enquiry under section 100 2 c , such as the mistake of the polling officer in issuing wrong ballot papers and its possible effect on the result of the voting, and that accordingly the decision was liable to be quashed by certiorari both on the ground of error of jurisdiction and error in the construction of section 100 2 c apparent on the face of the record. The first respondent, on the other hand, contended that the decision of the Tribunal that the 301 ballot papers found in his box should have been rejected under Rule 47 1 c was erroneous, because that rule was only directory and not mandatory and because the Election Commission had validated them, and that its decision was final. He also contended that even if the ballot papers in question were liable to be rejected under Rule 47 1 c , for the purpose of deciding under section 100 2 c whether the result of the election had been materially affected the Tribunal had to ascertain the true intention of the voters and the mistake of the polling officer under Rule 23 and its effect on the result of the election were matters which were within the scope of the enquiry under that section. The correctness of these contentions falls not to be determined. On the question whether Rule 47 1 c is mandatory, the argument of Mr. Pathak is that notwithstanding that the rule provides that the Returning Officer shall reject the ballot papers, its real meaning is that he has the power to reject them, and that on that construction, his discretion in the matter of accepting them is not liable to be questioned.

issues.text: whether the decision of the Election Tribunal under section 100 2 c that the result of the election had not been materially affected is bad, as it is based on considerations extraneous to that section.

anchor.surface_text: It remains to deal with the contention of the appellant that the decision of the Election Tribunal under section 100 2 c that the result of the election had not been materially affected is bad, as it is based on considerations extraneous to that section. This opens up the question as to the scope of an enquiry under section 100 2 c .

arguments.claim: High Courts have jurisdiction under Art 226 to issue writs against Election Tribunals

anchor.surface_text: The first question that arises for decision in this appeal is whether High Courts have jurisdiction under article 226 to issue writs against decisions of Election Tribunals. That article confers on High Courts power to issue appropriate writs to any person or authority within their territorial jurisdiction, in terms absolute and unqualified, and Election Tribunals functioning within the territorial jurisdiction of the High Courts would fall within the sweep of that power.

arguments.claim: Art 329(b) does not bar writ under 226 against tribunal decision; bars only initiation of proceedings

anchor.surface_text: In N. P. Ponnuswami v. Returning Officer, Namakkal Constituency and Others 1  it was held by this Court that the word election in article 329 b  was used in a comprehensive sense as including the entire process of election commencing with the issue of a notification

arguments.claim: Certiorari can issue to quash even if tribunal functus officio; directed at record

anchor.surface_text: If it is the record of the decision that has to be removed by certiorari, then the fact that the tribunal has become functus officio subsequent to the decision could have no effect on the jurisdiction of the court to remove the record.

arguments.claim: Election Tribunals subject to Art 227 superintendence

anchor.surface_text: We are also of opinion that the Election Tribunals are subject to the superintendence of the High Courts under article 227 of the Constitution, and that superintendence is both judicial and administrative.

anchor.surface_text: The first respondent, on the other hand, contended that the decision of the Tribunal that the 301 ballot papers found in his box should have been rejected under Rule 47 1 c was erroneous, because that rule was only directory and not mandatory and because the Election Commission had validated them, and that its decision was final. He also contended that even if the ballot papers in question were liable to be rejected under Rule 47 1 c , for the purpose of deciding under section 100 2 c whether the result of the election had been materially affected the Tribunal had to ascertain the true intention of the voters and the mistake of the polling officer under Rule 23 and its effect on the result of the election were matters which were within the scope of the enquiry under that section.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: must, unless there is something in the companytext companypelling a different interpretation, be companystrued in the same sense as in section 66, and

arguments.court_reasoning: Rejected votes cannot be counted for intention; RO/Tribunal no power to accept invalid votes

arguments.claim: Rule 47(1)(c) directory: 'shall' means power to reject; directory as public duty

anchor.surface_text: On the question whether Rule 47 1 c is mandatory, the argument of Mr. Pathak is that notwithstanding that the rule provides that the Returning Officer shall reject the ballot papers, its real meaning is that he has the power to reject them, and that on that construction, his discretion in the matter of accepting them is not liable to be questioned.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: must, unless there is something in the companytext companypelling a different interpretation, be companystrued in the same sense as in section 66, and

arguments.court_reasoning: Mandatory; no discretion; uniform with other sub-rules; no substantial compliance possible

arguments.claim: Election Commission validated votes; its decision final

anchor.surface_text: He relies on certain well-recognised rules of construction such as that a statute should be construed as directory if it relates to the performance of public duties, or if the conditions prescribed therein have to be performed by persons other than those on whom the right is conferred.

arguments.court_reasoning: EC cannot prescribe different marks post-polling; Rule 28 not altered

arguments.claim: Rule 47(1)(c) mandatory: 'shall' uniform across sub-rules; no degrees of compliance

anchor.surface_text: If the word shall is thus to be construed in a mandatory sense in Rule 47 1 a , b and d , it would be proper to construe it in the same sense in Rule 47 1 c also. There is another reason which clinches the matter against the first respondent.

arguments.claim: Improper reception under s100(2)(c) materially affects result as 301 > margin 174

anchor.surface_text: The contention of Mr. Chatterjee is that when once he has established that the Returning Officer had contravened Rule 47 1 c , he has also established that the result of the election had been materially affected, because the marginal difference between the appellant and the first respondent was only 174 votes,

arguments.claim: Under s100(2)(c), consider chain of breaches (Rule 23,28,47); voter intention paramount

arguments.court_reasoning: Cannot accept rejected votes; intention only if formally expressed

arguments.claim: s100(2)(c) enquiry limited to election petition grounds; no Rule 23 issue raised

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Chatterjee disputes this position, and contends that the enquiry under that section must be limited to the matters raised in the election petition, and that as there was no complaint about the breach of Rule 23 in that petition, it was outside the scope of the enquiry.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: t this Court companyld number entertain an appeal against the decision of an Election Tribunal under

arguments.court_reasoning: Recrimination under s97 brings it in

arguments.claim: No valid election due to s97 recrimination; both elections void

anchor.surface_text: The combined effect of section 97 and section 100 2 c is that there is no valid election.

holdings.text: High Courts have jurisdiction under Article 226 to issue writs of certiorari against decisions of Election Tribunals notwithstanding Article 329(b)

anchor.surface_text: The first question that arises for decision in this appeal is whether High Courts have jurisdiction under article 226 to issue writs against decisions of Election Tribunals. That article confers on High Courts power to issue appropriate writs to any person or authority within their territorial jurisdiction, in terms absolute and unqualified, and Election Tribunals functioning within the territorial jurisdiction of the High Courts would fall within the sweep of that power.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art 226 confers absolute power over authorities including tribunals; Art 329(b) bars only initiation of election challenges via election petition, not post-decision supervisory writs; precedent from Ponnuswami and Durga Shankar applied

holdings.text: Writ of certiorari to quash can issue even against decision of tribunal that has become functus officio

anchor.surface_text: By parity of reasoning it must be held that the power of the High Court under article 226 to issue writ of certiorari against decisions of Election Tribunals remains equally unaffected by article 329 b . It is next contended that even if there is jurisdic-

holdings.reasoning_summary: Certiorari to quash targets the record not the tribunal; issued to custodian of record under s103; English/American precedents distinguish from prohibition; functus officio irrelevant for quashing

holdings.text: Election Tribunals are subject to superintendence of High Courts under Article 227 both judicial and administrative

anchor.surface_text: We are also of opinion that the Election Tribunals are subject to the superintendence of the High Courts under article 227 of the Constitution, and that superintendence is both judicial and administrative.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedent from Waryam Singh; Art 227 wider than prior laws

holdings.text: Application for certiorari and other reliefs maintainable under Articles 226 and 227

anchor.surface_text: We must accordingly hold that the application of the appellant for a writ of certiorari and for other reliefs was maintainable under articles 226 and 227 of the Constitution. Then the question is whether there are proper grounds for the issue of certiorari in the present case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative from prior holdings on jurisdiction, functus, superintendence

holdings.text: Rule 47(1)(c) is mandatory requiring rejection of ballot papers without prescribed distinguishing mark

anchor.surface_text: If the word shall is thus to be construed in a mandatory sense in Rule 47 1 a , b and d , it would be proper to construe it in the same sense in Rule 47 1 c also. There is another reason which clinches the matter against the first respondent.

holdings.reasoning_summary: 'Shall reject' uniform across sub-rules a,b,d where mandatory; no degrees of compliance possible for rejection; distinguishes directory rules

holdings.text: Election Commission's post-polling approval does not validate ballot papers lacking prescribed mark under Rule 28

anchor.surface_text: The approval by the Election Commission subsequent to the polling, therefore, cannot render valid the 301 ballot papers which did not bear the distinguishing mark prescribed for the election, and they are liable to be rejected under Rule 47  1   c .

holdings.reasoning_summary: EC cannot alter Rule 28 mark post-polling; approval condones defect but does not change prescription; must precede poll per Rule 23

holdings.text: Tribunal erred in holding under s100(2)(c) that result not materially affected by considering extraneous matters like Rule 23 breach and voter intention

anchor.surface_text: It remains to deal with the contention of the appellant that the decision of the Election Tribunal under section 100 2 c that the result of the election had not been materially affected is bad, as it is based on considerations extraneous to that section.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s100(2)(c) limited to valid votes; cannot count rejected votes or speculate intention; Tribunal jurisdiction co-extensive with RO under Rule 47(4); error apparent on face warrants certiorari

holdings.text: Due to recrimination under s97, appellant's election also void; no valid election

anchor.surface_text: The combined effect of section 97 and section 100 2 c is that there is no valid election.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s97 allows challenge to petitioner's election; breaches at other stations void appellant's potential election; result based on valid votes only per Rule 48

holdings.text: Tribunal decision quashed by certiorari; election of first respondent set aside; fresh election

anchor.surface_text: This appeal must accordingly be allowed, the decisions of the High Court and the Tribunal quashed and the whole election set aside.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Error of law apparent on record; proper grounds for certiorari; no declaration for either due to mutual infirmities

justification_sets.label: Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support
